Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Inverse Problems for Electrical Networks
Award.AbstractNarration: The REU Program on Inverse Problems for Electrical Networks will bring eight undergraduates to the Department of Mathematics at the University of Washington in each of the summers 2008-10 to work on discrete inverse problems. The inverse problem for an electrical network is the problem of finding the conductivity of resistors and shape of a network when the boundary current response to boundary voltages (response matrix) is known. Resistances may be specified by directed or undirected edge functions or vertex functions. Students will investigate the relation between the response matrix and the geometry of the network. The students will also pursue related discrete problems involving Bruhat orders, Schubert varieties and tableaux.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The students and faculty in the REU program Inverse Problems for
Electrical Networks spent eight weeks in each of the last three summers
working on problems related to finding properties of  an
electrical network when certain values of measurements of voltage
and current at terminals of
the network are known.  There were a total of thirty-eight undergraduate
students, eight graduate student TAs, and five faculty in the program.

The participants discovered how to compute the
values of resistances and the shape of an electrical network in certain cases,
especially certain types of planar networks.  They also found networks
for which this is not possible but for which there is an n-fold set of
possibilities (n-1 graphs).  They studied both finite and infinite networks
and found results for non-planar graphs. They also studied properties of knots
and their projections in the plane.

After the first week each day was organized as follows.  Each student met
for a period of forty-five minutes to one hour with one of the faculty
or assistants. Students and faculty worked together on the problems.
This typically consisted of working on details of computations,
testing conjectures with examples, or working on details of proofs.  For
the faculty this occupied all of the day.  For the students the
remaining time was spent working with other students, writing computer
code, consulting texts and journals, or composing the finished paper in
latex.  Some of these papers have been submitted for publication in
prominent research journals. Each student made several oral presentations
to the whole
group.  At these talks the students handed out a printed copy of the
talk to the audience.  Many of these students are now graduate students at
prominent research universities.
